description: A high quality and and beautiful portal to the fediverse. Works great.
This is a very nicely designed alternative to the standard web-based interface.

Tuba is one of the more delightful apps I've used in recent history. I've taken pretty much every GTK-based Twitter and Mastodon app for a spin, and can say without reservation that Tuba is my favorite so far.

If I had to boil down my reasons for why the experience is so lovely, I would mark it down to these 4 things:

1. The built-in media viewer is unabtrusive, clever, and slick. Tapping or clicking an image makes it appear full-screen, and it's easy to jump back to the content when you're done. It also handles slideshows well.

2. It makes use of libadwaita's adaptive stylings really well. It goes from a pure list/stream of content, to an expanded view complete with sidepanes, and reasonable margins to fit ever-expanding window sizes. 

3. It provides settings for larger font sizes and line heights to make the reading experience more pleasant, but it doesn't weigh you down with endless sets of buttons or text fields to tweak every single variable. 

4. It features all the core Mastodon experiences (including local and federated timelines) in a way that doesn't feel like an afterthought.

All in all, I'm quite impressed, and look forward to seeing more updates appear, because I know they'll bring quality as well. Great job!

Pros: As the title says. It works great. Everything is snappy and smooth navigating,it was easy to set up, and feature and function works properly. 

Cons: it's ugly, but also doesn't do well at a full screen size. Tuba was clearly designed for Linux phone. 

The GNOME design philosophy is not good for apps. buttons get put in places that are annoying to go to, even if they move when resized. It breaks it's own philosophy of being out of the way by trying to condense too much 

Switching accounts doesn't need to be in a drop-down, and frankly stops me from wanting to use them. These are options you want available, not hidden. 

The settings and preferences are a bit too simplistic to fix the problems it has with resizing. Going from a phone sized, vertical window to full screen creates large gaps that centres the timeline and looks really bad by constraining all the text to the same sized centred timeline area. 

I'm by far someone cares about aesthetics all that much, but I do care about user experience, and until these specific things can be changed in the preferences I would love it.

Another review put it very well: I can't believe this is a GNOME app and not something in the Apple ecosystem. It's an inspiration to everyone writing apps for this platform.

* when scrolling back in Home, there is a limit about 2 days ago, it just doesn't keep going. No way to override, no configurable setting. this was the main reason why I even installed a client, because the mastodon webgui has such a limit. The hoped-for advantage of a dedicated client did not materialize.
* when clicking on a post, it opens in the conversation, but going back to the timeline repositions at "now" instead of restoring the point where i was, a nightmare! (it even briefly flashes the old position and then goes away from it). cursor-keys are rebound to the newest post, instead of "cursor-up" repositioning at where I was. After scrolling to the right post (tedious) i find it unclear where to click to make it the keyboard focus without opening the thread.
* it doesn't seem to tooltip-display the post timestamp exactly when hovering on the e.g. "Feb 20" like the mastodon webgui does
* several icon characters used in the GUI are replaced by a grey warning sign, apparently it doesn't include fonts needed. e.g. the compose button at the bottom right (tooltip explains what it does) or the menu button on an individual post (no tooltip), conversations and follow requests in the menu
* it is unclear where I would switch "show replies" in home on or off, but it seems to have kept my Mastodon webgui setting (show replies: yes) - the setting is not in Preferences and there is no menu for the Home view min particular
* when navigating cursor-up/down to jump by one post at a time, the border around the active post quickly disappears leaving me at a loss which one is the selected one until I press a cursor key again. the Mastodon webgui behaviour that cursor up/down without a focus post scrolls by small amount per keypress doesn't seem to exist, at least moving by post makes an effort to display the whole selected post
* pulling the window wider does not make use of the space by widening the timeline, it just displayed grey background around it
